recipe.description:
Fragrant, spicy and slightly sweet, this dish is sure to become a fast favourite! These delicious duck breasts may have been raised on a farm in East Anglia, but we have given them an Asian twist in this easy, yet impressive dish.

The meat is Gressingham duck®, a unique breed known for having a higher percentage of breast meat and extra deliciousness! Paired with crunchy pak choi and noodles, this dish is packed full of flavour. 

Wine Recommendation

Chateauneuf des Papes Blaston du Rhone, £13.99, Ocado

The richness of duck meat matches well with a hearty wine. Pinot noir is a natural, but here we have chosen a Chateau Neuf du Pape which goes beautifully with the chinese five spice and star anise. Or if you prefer a white wine, try something slightly sweet, such as this Champteloup Vouvray, 2011, £7.03

Music Recommendation

Try out our Asian Fusion playlist http://spoti.fi/RcJbvx

In this one we've gone for some exquisit mixture of chillout house music with far-eastern sprinkles. One of the bands featured, Ancient Future, is a multinational combo of musicians who blend ancient musical traditions with modern musical elements such as jazz or house. Definitely not your standard Chinese restaurant background music

Ingredients List (what Dinnr brings you)
320g Duck Breasts, 200g Noodles, 2 Pak Choi, 3 Spring Onions, 6g Chinese Black Mushrooms, 2 tbsp (30ml) Soy Sauce, 1 tsp Chinese Five Spice Powder, 2 Star Anise, 1 tbsp Honey, 1 Stock Cube, 0.5 tsp Dried Chilli Flakes
What you need at home
Equipment Required
Oven Proof Frying Pan, Or a normal frying pan and a baking tray, Saucepan, Sharp Knife, Chopping Board, Wooden Spoon
Nutrition Info (per person)
(per serving) 848 Calories 81g Protein 23g Fat 86g Carbs
Allergy Information
Contains Gluten and Soy Beans
